title: J. R. Reid
text:
Herman "J. R." Reid Jr. (born March 31, 1968) is an American <a href="basketball">basketball</a> coach and former professional player who is an assistant coach for the <a href="Monmouth%20Hawks%20men%27s%20basketball">Monmouth Hawks men's basketball team</a>. He played in the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a> (NBA) for the <a href="Charlotte%20Hornets">Charlotte Hornets</a>, <a href="San%20Antonio%20Spurs">San Antonio Spurs</a>, <a href="New%20York%20Knicks">New York Knicks</a>, <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Lakers">Los Angeles Lakers</a>, <a href="Milwaukee%20Bucks">Milwaukee Bucks</a> and <a href="Cleveland%20Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a>. Reid played <a href="college%20basketball">college basketball</a> for the <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20men%27s%20basketball">North Carolina Tar Heels</a> and was a consensus first-team <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20All-Americans">All-American</a> as a sophomore in <a href="1988%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20All-Americans">1988</a>. He won a bronze medal as a member of the <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20basketball%20team">United States national team</a> at the <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">1988 Summer Olympics</a>.
Early life and high school career.
Reid was born and raised in <a href="Virginia%20Beach%2C%20Virginia">Virginia Beach, Virginia</a>, and was the son of Herman Reid Sr., who played <a href="American%20football">football</a> in the 1960s with the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>. Reid played football himself in his early years as a defensive player and his gridiron skills even caught the attention of the <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech Hokies</a>, but he decided to stick with playing basketball. Reid starred at <a href="Kempsville%20High%20School">Kempsville High School</a> in Virginia Beach, being named the 1986 Gatorade and "USA Today" Player of the Year. He certified his reputation by being named most valuable player (MVP) of both the <a href="1986%20McDonald%27s%20All-American%20Boys%20Game">1986 McDonald's Game</a> and the Capital Classic.
College career.
Reid played <a href="college%20basketball">college basketball</a> for the <a href="North%20Carolina%20Tar%20Heels%20men%27s%20basketball">North Carolina Tar Heels</a> from 1986 to 1989. He was named <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year">ACC Rookie of the Year</a> in 1987 as he averaged 14.7 points and 7 rebounds per game. During his freshman year at UNC, he was featured on the March 2, 1987 cover of <a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a> magazine. During his sophomore season, he was named a consensus first-team <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20All-Americans">All-American</a> when he averaged 18 points and 8.9 rebounds per game.
Reid was named to the <a href="1988%20United%20States%20men%27s%20Olympic%20basketball%20team">1988 United States men's Olympic basketball team</a> to compete at the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>. He played in six games and averaged 6 points per game.
Professional career.
He was drafted by the <a href="Charlotte%20Hornets">Charlotte Hornets</a> as the 5th overall pick in the <a href="1989%20NBA%20draft">1989 NBA draft</a>. On February 25, 1996, in a game against the <a href="Phoenix%20Suns">Phoenix Suns</a>, <a href="A.%20C.%20Green">A. C. Green</a> mentioned an incident at a New York City club before Reid hit him with a vicious right elbow in the mouth during the fourth quarter of the game, knocking out two of Green's teeth. Reid was suspended for two games and fined $10,000 for intentionally throwing an elbow and knocking out two of Green's teeth.
Post-playing career.
After his NBA career, he competed to become an analyst on the former <a href="ESPN">ESPN</a> TV show "<a href="Dream%20Job">Dream Job</a>", but lost. In 2011, he was named an assistant coach for <a href="Patrick%20%26amp%3B%20Henry%20Community%20College">Patrick & Henry Community College</a>. He was hired as an assistant to former UNC teammate <a href="King%20Rice">King Rice</a> in 2018.
